stem: The nurse is reviewing the developmental milestones of four pediatric clients. Based on the provided information, match each client's behavior to the appropriate age range.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
**07:00**
S: Receiving report on four pediatric clients. A.B., male, 6 months old, admitted for routine well-child check-up. Parents report he can roll over and sit with support.
B.C., female, 12 months old, presents for follow-up after URI. Observed to be pulling up to stand and cruising along furniture.
C.D., male, 18 months old, here for immunization. Parents state he can walk independently and attempts to feed himself with a spoon.
D.E., female, 9 months old, readmitted for dehydration secondary to gastroenteritis. Previously able to transfer objects from one hand to the other and babble.

**07:15**
S: D.E. appears slightly lethargic upon initial assessment, but is easily roused by verbal stimuli.

B: A.B., B.C., C.D. are stable and within normal limits.

A: Continue to monitor all patients as per standard pediatric protocols.

R: Anticipate discharge planning for A.B. and C.D. Educate parents on age-appropriate milestones and safety precautions. Continue rehydration therapy for D.E. and monitor for improvement. Monitor B.C. for respiratory distress given recent URI diagnosis.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
A.B. (6 months): Alert, active, able to roll over. Sits with support. Follows objects with eyes.
B.C. (12 months): Alert, active, pulling up to stand. Cruising along furniture. Responds to name.
C.D. (18 months): Alert, active, walking independently. Attempts to feed self with spoon. Says several single words.
D.E. (9 months): Lethargic, but arousable. Decreased skin turgor. Mucous membranes dry. Transfers objects hand to hand. Babbles.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
A.B. (6 months): Routine well-child care, administer vaccines as appropriate.
B.C. (12 months): Monitor respiratory status, administer antipyretics if needed.
C.D. (18 months): Administer immunizations as appropriate, assess developmental progress.
D.E. (9 months): Continue IV rehydration, monitor electrolytes, assess skin turgor and mucous membranes.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
D.E. (9 months):
06:30: IV fluids 0.9% NaCl 20 mL/kg bolus ordered. Acetaminophen prn for fever.

rows.text: A.B. (6 months): Rolls over and sits with support.
B.C. (12 months): Pulls up to stand and cruises along furniture.
C.D. (18 months): Walks independently and attempts to feed himself with a spoon.
D.E. (9 months): Transfers objects from one hand to the other and babbles.

rationale.correct: Developmental milestones are age-specific achievements that reflect a child's growth and maturation. Rolling over and sitting with support are typical milestones for a 6-month-old. Pulling up to stand and cruising along furniture are milestones typically achieved by 12 months. Walking independently and attempting to self-feed with a spoon are characteristic of an 18-month-old. Transferring objects from one hand to another and babbling are milestones typically observed in 9-month-old infants.
rationale.incorrect: Selecting the incorrect age range indicates a misunderstanding of the expected sequence and timing of developmental milestones. Each milestone is associated with a specific age range, and deviations may indicate developmental delays or other underlying issues.

answerBreakdown.text: A.B. (6 months): Rolls over and sits with support.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Rolling over and sitting with support are gross motor skills typically achieved around 6 months of age, indicating normal development for this age group.

answerBreakdown.text: B.C. (12 months): Pulls up to stand and cruises along furniture.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Pulling up to stand and cruising are motor skills that indicate progression towards independent walking, typically seen around 12 months of age.

answerBreakdown.text: C.D. (18 months): Walks independently and attempts to feed himself with a spoon.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Walking independently and attempting self-feeding are indicative of increasing independence and fine motor skills, typically observed around 18 months.

answerBreakdown.text: D.E. (9 months): Transfers objects from one hand to the other and babbles.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Transferring objects between hands and babbling are fine motor and language skills expected around 9 months of age, indicating appropriate development.

clinicalPearls: Developmental milestones provide a framework for assessing a child's progress and identifying potential delays or concerns.
Factors such as prematurity, illness, and environment can influence the timing of developmental milestones.
Regular monitoring and assessment of developmental milestones are essential components of pediatric care.

questionTrap.trap: Students often confuse milestones that occur close in age, especially between 6-9 months and 12-18 months.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the specific skills described. For example, 'walking independently' is much later than 'pulling to stand'. Pay attention to fine motor skills (like self-feeding) versus gross motor skills (like rolling over).

mnemonic.title: SMART Milestones
mnemonic.expansion: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound. Use this framework to remember the expected progression of milestones.
